content.description: This route makes for a good warm-up. Traverse the entire main wall at Swan Mountain.
content.protection: A boulder pad and a spotter.
content.location: Start at the beginning of the Swan Mountain area, and traverse the whole main wall.

content.description: This is a nice, tall, boulder problem just short of being HB. It has interesting sidepull moves on a perfectly vertical face.
content.location:
It is on the uphill (east) side of

The Island

. Thsi is to the left of the major crack and right of the arete.

content.description: The name, "Bat Cave", comes from how much time you spend hanging under this problem. A sit start on the right inside the "cave" has good holds and easy feet for the first several moves. Work your hands to the left and you feet high right till you're almost horizontal. Then you can either reach high over the bulge for some blind holds or work further left for some tough skinny crimps. Topping off this one is hard but fun, make sure you have a spotter and good pad. Also a good warm up for the Onion Roll (V7), found just down the hill.
content.location: As soon as you drop into the traverse wall, follow a trail left (downhill) and it is the first, obvious, overhanging boulder.

content.description: Sit start on the left and traverse to the right on the big holds. Starts out easy then gets more challenging as you reach the sloper rail section. Continue all the way to the right. Foot placement is key.
content.protection: A crash pad. A spotter to move the pad is nice also.
content.location: As soon as you walk down the steps to the traverse wall, take a left down the hill, pass the first over hanging boulder on your left, and continue down the hill for 50 feet or so, and you will see the top of the Onion.

content.description:
The lone chunk of rock separated from the Traverse Wall. I could only choose one rating, so I went with the V0. That describes most of the problems here. There are a few harder problems. A traverse to the left starting between The Island and the Main Wall all the way around includes some V2 moves.

This has a good, easy, highball on the downhill side and some nice, crimpy climbs on the uphill side. An easy walk down on the north side makes this a great rock.
content.location: This is at the far end of the Swan Mountain Traverse Wall.

content.description: Start in a messy chimney, and move interestingly to a thin face to jugs.
content.location: It is next to last TR that you come to, just before a broken chimney.

content.description: This is a SDS problem on the center of the Onion Roll Boulder.  Both hands start on the same hold that is just below the sloper rail that is used for the onion roll traverse and to the right of the big jugs, feet flagged out left.  Move your left hand up first to sloper rail, heel hook your left foot, then move right hand up to same sloper rail, move your left hand up to crimp/pinch, then top out.  Left heel hook and legs flagged out left are key to this problem.
content.location: It is found at the Swan Mountain Boulders, on the Onion Roll Boulder.

content.description: This is a nice route. It is essentially a topropeable boulder problem.
content.location: It is the farthest left route.

content.description: This is the third TR that you come to.
content.protection: There are anchors at the top.
content.location: It is the third TR that you come to.

content.description:
This is the same type of climb as the other

5.6 TR - 1

but just a bit shorter.
content.protection:
Rope to two bolts.

Per

Nolanic

: the anchors were no longer there!

Per

Steeler S

: there are now 3 anchor bolts and a 4th to the right.
content.location:
It is to the left of the other

5.6 TR - 1

when looking at the rock.

content.description: This is a great climb for someone learning to climb belay and or rappel.  It has great views of Lake Dillon, too!!!
content.protection: Rope and two (now only one) top anchors.
content.location: Follow the path to Swan Mtn bouldering area, but do not enter.  Stay high on the trail for an extra ten minutes.  After the trail takes a left turn (about 1/4 mile), walk down hill to the nearest opening in the trees and follow the cliff band until you reach another downhill path.  The anchors to this route are just before the second path.
